ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned the most from this class out of any class I've taken at Yale. It has completely and fundamentally changed how I act and interact. I am a much better listener, friend, and leader because of Peter.
I learned so much about myself and what leadership truly means. This is a must take class for anyone who wants to improve their interpersonal skills and become a better person.

I developed so many skills:

How to listen effectively (sounds simple, but this was HUGE and radically changed my relationships), 
the importance of body language, how to create psychological safety on teams (i.e.: where people feel comfortable to disagree), 
how to ask good questions, 
how to create positive affect in your relationships, 
the importance of intellectual humility (not selling more than you actually know), grew as a public speaker, 
learned how to have tough, high-stakes conversations with people (friends, coworkers, you name it), 
how to write concisely and in plain language, how to create positive affect in romantic relationships, 
how to take on interpersonal risk, 
how to give and receive feedback better, 
learned what my character strengths were (huge), 
and more.

Don't be fooled by my brevity. I learned so much more. Legitimately the best class I've ever taken at Yale.

This class didn't just teach me how to be a better leader, but also a better person. This class will change how you view relationships and conversations. It teaches you some fundamental techniques for engaging better with the people in your life. The skills you learn in the class will be helpful in all domains of your life--writing, academics, communication, leadership roles etc.

I learned practical and applicable leadership skills such as effective and empathetic listening, engaging in crucial conversations, taking and giving feedback, setting a growth mindset, etc. Through class assignments, I applied these skills in interviewing people, starting crucial conversations with people I care about etc.

I learned how to be a better person. That is not an overstatement; that is a fact. Among many other skills, this course provided an opportunity to hone the core leadership behaviors of listening, expressing gratitude, and asking questions. I also learned so much from Peter's example.

Practical Skills: 
Speaking, Listening, How to carry oneself in a workplace, what are behaviors that encompass a strong leader
being a better person, partner, friend..

I learned how to be a good person in this class. All Yalies should be required to take LAByou learn how to listen, how to navigate tough conversations, how to give/receive feedback, and more. These are all vital skills that we rarely get the chance to practice, and this class gives you a great place and reason to.
This class was one of the best classes I have ever taken. You learn so many practical skills.
In this course, I learned various skills across the spectrum, including leadership, analytical thinking, the ability to handle feedback, and interacting with different people, among many others.
Leadership as behavior and how the qualities of listening, communication, and teamwork.

This course taught me to be a better leader, first by reframing what it even means to be a good leader. This course frames a leaders as someone who has the skills in empathy, critical communication, listening, and public speaking needed to understand a team, create an environment of psychological safety, and lead. This course taught me to become a better writer, communicator, and person.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: So, so many strengths. Peter is the most caring and supportive professor I've ever had at Yale. The course material could not be more applicable. The class culture/environment is unmatched. No weaknesses.

The strengths are the format and the reading assignments. You sit in a circle for 2 hours and have intellectually stimulating and engaging conversations with others who also want to improve themselves. The readings were interesting and insightful. I plan to return to them frequently as I progress in my professional career. 

There are no weaknesses.

Strengths:
- Peter (professor) is a phenomenal teacher and leader. He's thoughtful, kind, detail-oriented and I've never seen a professor more prepared than he is every week; I'm not exaggerating (if you take the class you'll see what I mean). Peter is the most organized professor I've ever had, and he's only a guest lecturer lol. Man raises the bar so, so high. 
- The material is so, so good. I have a running notes doc of everything we covered in this class in list format that I'll be returning to and adding to for years to come, no doubt about it.
- The community of students within the class is so wonderful. It gives secret society vibes, without any of the elitist undertones. Everyone is so diverse and thoughtful and bought in, and it makes coming to class everyday to dang exciting. Not your typical Yale seminar.
- What you learn: the things you learn aren't solely applicable to being a better leader. It's really skills to help you grow to become better teammates, friends, siblings, and romantic partners. 
- Being in blackbox theater is DOPE
- Love how experimental this class was. You didn't just sit in a blackbox theater and talk about the principles we learned in theory. You had to (cuz it was homework) go out and implement it in a real relationship that you have. And I love that. Most classes you take, you learn material and forget it right after the semester is over. Not this class.
- The handouts he makes are fire. 
- No phones allowed vibe is Dope!

Weaknesses:
- We did a lot of public speaking, but wish we got more feedback in real time and worked it more intentionally (nitpicky)
- Wish we learned more low-level conversational/body-language skills (like attending behavior/listeningI loved this).
- Wish Peter shared more anecdotes to enrich the things we were learning  so we could see how the things we're learning about in abstract can be done well/poorly IRL.

This is one of the best courses this college offers--it makes you learn things that apply to fundamental aspects of your life. The assignments are unique and make you think a lot about your life--past, present, and future. The class activities are well-structured, and you learn a lot about the people taking the class with you. The people taking the class are very driven and engaging--they feel passionate about the topic and bring unique insights to the class. I wish I could get to know them even more outside the class! Peter is a fantastic presence to have in class. He leads by example and makes every session memorable. He goes the extra mile to meet you one-on-one multiple times throughout the semester and help you with the class/life in general. He cares very deeply about the class, which is visible in the amount of effort he puts into it. He makes sure the class is an enjoyable experience, both in the classroom and outside of it. Can't say enough about the class! No big weaknesses come to mind- I learned a lot from the class.

Strengths: Peter is such a great instructor. He is the best professor I've ever had. He cares so much about everyone, offering time to meet with us one-on-one outside of class time to get to know our stories. share his story with us and help us with the final papers. During class time, he is very engaging, paying attention to what everyone says and great at facilitating the class. He really helped to build a trusting community in the class, not just 20 strangers sitting in one classroom. I never felt judged or uncomfortable to say what I want because of his effort in building such a great community. He also takes feedback very well. In mid-semester, he took out half of the class specifically for giving feedback on how the course is going and how he could change things. After we gave feedback, he implemented those feedback. 
The class is very organized. Everything is clear in the syllabus. He communicates assignments and expectations well in advance so there are no surprises. The workload isn't too much, just one page of writing every week. Peter gives specific and detailed feedback on every assignment and has helped me to become better at clear writing. 
No weaknesses. This is the best class I've ever taken at Yale, period. If you get into this class, take it.

Strengths: This course is about as perfect as any earthly course can be. It is the most organized and thoughtfully designed course I have ever taken at Yale, and I've taken some phenomenal courses here. Peter is a god. He is a necessary and sufficient ingredient for this course's excellence. He truly practices what he preaches. He gives detailed, actionable, and copious feedback. He truly cares. I cannot praise him highly enough.
Weaknesses: None.
great course! more oral presentation opportunities and direct feedback
Extremely well-organized, Peter couldn't be more prepared if he tried.
This class is amazing! You learn so much about yourself and how to lead others

This course has no weaknesses.

Strengths:

Peter comes to every class well-organized, and everything is clear and well-taught.
Peter is more engaging than any other professor I had at Yale.
Peter is willing to go above and beyond to help the students.
Peter encourages students to forge their own paths and also allows them to grow and improve in their personal lives.

The biggest strength is Peter Bensinger. He is the most amazing professor and has such great care and love for his students. He goes above and beyond to create a comforting and supportive classroom environment.

Strengths -- Peter is the most involved, thoughtful, and prepared professor I have ever had. I thought the course was meticulously well designed.
Weaknesses -- None

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES
YES!!!!!! I cannot recommend it enough. #1 class I recommend to friends.
Absolutely.

ABSOLUTELY. DO NOT READ ANY OTHER COMMENT THAN THIS ONE RIGHT HERE. THIS IS THE BEST CLASS YOU WILL TAKE AT YALE AND I MEAN THAT. 

Seriously though, Leadership as Behavior is the class that you come to Yale to take.

Yes, yes, yes, a hundred times over! This course is not just about leadership--it will change how you approach all of your relationships and daily interactions. Peter is a gem of a professor to work with, and there's a lot to learn from him. If you are able to get in, do not give up your spot--it's probably the most helpful college course you will ever take. You will not regret it!
100% best class I have every taken at Yale. If you get the chance to learn from Peter take it!

YES! If you get in, 100% take this class. I was initially hesitant about taking the class because the title "Leadership as Behavior" seemed very vague and seemed like a self-help course that only teaches the concepts with no real takeaway. I was blown away by this course. Not only I get practical and applicable leadership skills, I think I became a better person. I got better at navigating my personal and professional relationships. You'll learn so much not only from Peter but also from your classmates as well.
YES! This is the best course I've taken at Yale. I LOVED it. Take it if you can! Truly some of the most useful hours I've ever spent learning anything.
Yes 100%, favorite course at Yale. You will become a better, more self-aware person after this course!!
Truly the most impactful class I took at Yale. If you get in this class, you take it.
Yes!
Every student at Yale should make it their goal to take this course. This course embodies what Yale is all about the ability to push students to become better leaders.
Every student, if accepted, needs to take this course. It should be called "how to become a better person!"

Yes, yes, yes! I don't say this lightly: my favorite course at Yale. This course changed how I understand other people, how to handle stressful conversations, how to give good feedback, how to listen better, how to be a better partner, how to writer clearer, and--overall--how to be a better person. Peter is prepared, thoughtful, and intentional. He makes an immense effort to understand his students and support their individual needs. I was excited for class every Thursday and always left feeling energized.
